translated: And it is said in the noble Ratnamegha: He who is skilled in this way in the faults, for the sake of being free from all conceptual proliferation, applies himself to the cultivation of emptiness.

original: sa śūnyatābhāvanābahulo yeṣu yeṣu sthāneṣu cittaṃ prasarati cittamabhiramate tāni tāni sthānāni svabhāvataḥ Bhk
analyzed: sa śūnyatā bhāvanā bahulaḥ yeṣu yeṣu sthāneṣu cittam prasarati cittam abhiramate tāni tāni sthānāni svabhāvataḥ
translated: He who is abundant in the cultivation of emptiness, wherever the mind spreads and delights, those places he sees as empty of intrinsic nature.

original: parigaveṣamāṇaḥ śūnyaṃ pratividhyati yat cittaṃ tadapi parīkṣamāṇaṃ śūnyaṃ pratividhyati yenāpi cittena parīkṣate tad api svabhāvataḥ parigaveṣyamāṇaṃ
analyzed: parigaveṣamāṇaḥ śūnyam pratividhyati yat cittam tat api parīkṣamāṇam śūnyam pratividhyati yena api cittena parīkṣate tat api svabhāvataḥ parigaveṣyamāṇam
translated: When searching, one penetrates emptiness. That mind, when examined, one penetrates emptiness. Even with whatever mind one examines, that too, when sought in its own nature,

analyzed: śūnyam pratividhyati
translated: one penetrates emptiness.

analyzed: saḥ evam upaparīkṣamāṇaḥ nirnimitta tāyām yogam āpadyate
translated: Examining in this way, one applies oneself to signlessness.

analyzed: tat eva anena evam darśitam bhavati
translated: This is shown by him in this way.

original: yastu nopaparīkṣate tasya nāsti nirnimittatāyāṃ praveśa iti /
analyzed: yaḥ tu na upaparīkṣate tasya na asti nirnimitta tāyām praveśaḥ iti
translated: But for one who does not examine, there is no entry into signlessness.

original: sa evaṃ dharmāṇāṃ svabhāvamupaparīkṣamāṇo yada nopalabhate /
analyzed: saḥ evam dharmāṇām svabhāvam upaparīkṣamāṇaḥ na upalabhate
translated: He, examining in this way the nature of phenomena, when he does not find,

original: tadāstīti na vikalpayati nāstīti na vikalpayati /
analyzed: tat ā asti iti na vikalpayati na asti iti na vikalpayati
translated: he does not conceive it exists, he does not conceive it does not exist.

original: yo 'sau nāstīti kalpyate tasya buddhau sarvadaivāpratibhāsanāt /
analyzed: na asti iti kalpyate tasya buddhau sarvadā eva apratibhāsanāt
translated: Because that which is conceived as it does not exist never appears in his mind.

original: yadi hi bhāvaḥ kadācid dṛṣṭo bhavet /
analyzed: yadi hi bhāvaḥ kadācid dṛṣṭaḥ bhavet
translated: For if an existent thing could be seen at some time,

analyzed: tadā tasya pratiṣedhāt na asti iti kalpayet
translated: then, by negating it, one could conceive it does not exist.

original: yadā kālatraye 'pi yoginā prajñayā nirūpayatā bhāvo nopalabdhaḥ tadā kasya pratiṣedhān nāstīti kalpayet /
analyzed: yadā kāla traye yoginā prajñayā nirūpayatā bhāvaḥ na upalabdhaḥ tadā kasya pratiṣedhāt na asti iti kalpayet
translated: But when a yogi, examining with wisdom in the three times, does not find an existent thing, then what is negated, by what is conceived it does not exist?

original: evamanye vikalpāstasya tadānīṃ na santi eva /
analyzed: evam anye vikalpāḥ tasya tadānīm na santi eva
translated: In this way, other conceptual thoughts do not exist at that time.

analyzed: bhāva abhāva vikalpābhyām sarvasya vikalpasya vyāpta tvāt
translated: Because all conceptual thoughts are pervaded by the concepts of existence and non-existence.

analyzed: evam vyāpaka abhāvāt byāpyasya api abhāvaḥ
translated: Thus, due to the absence of the pervader, the pervaded also does not exist.

analyzed: evam sati niṣprapañca nirvikalpa tām avatīrṇaḥ bhavati
translated: When this is so, one has entered the state of being free from conceptual proliferation and free from conceptual thoughts.

analyzed: rūpa ādiṣu ca a niśritaḥ bhavati
translated: And one does not rely on form and so on.

original: prajñayā ca nirūpayataḥ sakalavastusvabhāvānupalambhāt prajñottaradhyāyī bhavati /
analyzed: prajñayā ca nirūpayataḥ sakala vastu svabhāva anupalambhāt prajñā uttara dhyāyī bhavati
translated: And because one who analyzes with wisdom does not perceive the nature of all things, one becomes a meditator who is superior in wisdom.

analyzed: saḥ evam pudgala dharma nairātmya mayam tattvam avatīrṇaḥ
translated: Having thus entered the reality that consists of the selflessness of persons and phenomena,

analyzed: aparasya parīkṣaṇīyasya ca abhāvāt
translated: and because there is nothing else to be examined,

analyzed: uparata vicāreṇa nirvikalpa eka rasena manasā sva rasa vāhinā
translated: with a mind that has ceased examination, that is one-pointed in non-conceptuality, that flows naturally,

original: anabhisaṃskārataḥ tad eva tattvaṃ sphuṭataram avadhārayan yogī tiṣṭheta /
analyzed: an abhisaṃskārataḥ tat eva tattvam sphuṭataram avadhārayan yogī tiṣṭheta
translated: the yogi should remain, clearly ascertaining that very reality without fabrication.

analyzed: tatra ca sthitaḥ citta bandham na vikṣipet
translated: And while remaining in that, he should not scatter the binding of the mind.

original: yadāntarā cittaṃ bahirdhā vikṣiptaṃ paśyet tadā tatsvabhāvapratyevekṣaṇena vikṣepaṃ praśamayya /
analyzed: yadā antarā cittam bahirdhā vikṣiptam paśyet tadā tad svabhāva pratyevekṣaṇena vikṣepam praśamayya
translated: When he sees that the mind is scattered externally at some point, then by observing the nature of that [mind], he should pacify the distraction.

analyzed: punar tatra eva cittam upari upari prerayet
translated: And again, he should direct his mind higher and higher right there.

analyzed: yadā tu tatra an abhiratam cittam paśyet
translated: But when he sees that his mind is not delighted there,

analyzed: tadā samādheḥ guṇa darśanāt abhiratim tatra thāvayet
translated: then, by seeing the virtues of concentration, he should generate delight there.

original: vikṣepe ca doṣadarśanād aratiṃ praśamayet /🔽atha styānamiddhābhibhavād yada pracāratayā līnaṃ cittaṃ paśyet /
analyzed: vikṣepe ca doṣa darśanāt aratim praśamayet  atha styānam iddha abhibhavāt pracāra tayā līnam cittam paśyet
translated: And by seeing the faults in distraction, he should remove disliking.🔽Now, if he sees that his mind is slack due to lack of activity, or is suspected of slackness,

original: layābhiśaṅkitaṃ vā tadā pramodyavastu buddharūpādikamālokasaṃjñāṃ vā manasikṛtya layamupaśamayet /
analyzed: laya abhiśaṅkitam vā tadā pramodya vastu buddha rūpa ādikam āloka saṃjñām vā manasi kṛtya layam upaśamayet
translated: then, by attending to things that inspire joy, such as the form of the Buddha, or the perception of light, he should remove slackness.

original: tatastad eva tattvaṃ dṛḍhataraṃ Bhk gṛṇhīyāt /
analyzed: tatas tat eva tattvam dṛḍhataram bhk
translated: Then, he should firmly grasp that very reality.

original: yadā tu jātyandhavad andhakārapraviṣṭapuruṣavad vinimīlitākṣavat sphuṭataraṃ tattvaṃ nāvadhārayed yogī /
analyzed: yadā tu jātyandha vat andhakāra praviṣṭa puruṣa vat vinimīlita akṣa vat sphuṭataram tattvam na avadhārayet yogī
translated: But when the yogi does not clearly ascertain reality like one born blind, like a person who has entered darkness, like one with closed eyes,

original: tadā tasya līnaṃ cittaṃ veditavyaṃ vipaśyanārahitaṃ ca /
analyzed: tadā tasya līnam cittam veditavyam vipaśyanā rahitam ca
translated: then his mind should be known as slack, devoid of insight.

original: atha yathā pūrvānubhūtaviṣayaspṛhayā cittamantarā samuddhataṃ paśyed /
analyzed: atha yathā pūrva anubhūta viṣaya spṛhayā cittam antarā samuddhatam paśyet
translated: Now, if he sees the mind agitated in between due to longing for an object previously experienced,

analyzed: auddhatya abhiśaṅkitam vā
translated: or suspected of agitation,

analyzed: tadā anitya tā ādi saṃvega vastu manasikārāt auddhatyam śamayet
translated: then he should remove agitation by attending to things that inspire disgust, such as impermanence.

original: tataḥ punaḥ tatraiva tattve cittānabhisaṃskāravāhitāyāṃ yatnaṃ kurvīta /
analyzed: tatas punar tatra eva tattve citta anabhisaṃskāra vāhi tāyām yatnam kurvīta
translated: Then, again, one should make an effort to keep the mind flowing without fabrication right there in that reality.

original: yadā ca vikṣiptapuruṣavad vānaravad vānavasthitavṛtti cittaṃ bhavet /
analyzed: yadā ca vikṣipta puruṣa vat vānara vat vā anavasthita vṛtti cittam bhavet
translated: And when the mind becomes unsteady like a distracted person or a monkey,

analyzed: tat auddhatyam boddhavyam śamatha rahitam ca
translated: then one should recognize that as restlessness, which is devoid of śamatha.

original: atha yadā layauddhatyābhyāṃ viviktatayā samapravṛttaṃ svarasavāhi sphuṭataraṃ tatraiva tattve cittam utpādyate tadābhogaśithilīkaraṇād upekṣaṇiyam
analyzed: atha yadā laya auddhatyābhyām vivikta tayā sama pravṛttam sva rasa vāhi sphuṭataram tatra eva tattve cittam utpādyate tad ābhoga śithilīkaraṇāt
translated: But when the mind is produced right there in that reality, flowing naturally with even activity, free from dullness and restlessness, then one should let it be, relaxing the exertion.

analyzed: tadā ca śamatha vipaśyanā yuga naddha vāhī mārgaḥ niṣpannaḥ veditavyaḥ
translated: Then, the path of the yoked practice of śamatha and vipaśyanā should be known as accomplished.

original: yadā ca vipaśyanā bhāvayet prajñātiriktatarā bhāvayet /
analyzed: yadā ca vipaśyanā bhāvayet prajñā atiriktatarā bhāvayet
translated: And when one cultivates vipaśyanā, cultivating wisdom as predominant,

original: tadā śamathasyālpatvāt pravātasthitapradipavat pracalatvāccittasya na sphuṭataraṃ tattvadarśanaṃ bhavet /
analyzed: tadā śamathasya alpa tvāt pravāta sthita pradipa vat pracala tvāt cittasya na sphuṭataram tattva darśanam bhavet
translated: then, due to the smallness of śamatha, the mind being unsteady like a lamp in the wind, the clear seeing of reality will not occur.

analyzed: atas tadā śamathaḥ bhāvayitavyaḥ
translated: Therefore, at that time, śamatha should be cultivated.

original: śamathasyābhyādhikye middhāvaṣṭabadhapuruṣasyeva sphuṭataraṃ tattvadarśanaṃ na syāt /
analyzed: śamathasya ābhyādhikye sphuṭataram tattva darśanam na syāt
translated: If śamatha is excessive, the clear seeing of reality will not occur like a person overpowered by sleep.

analyzed: tasmāt tadā prajñā bhāvayitavyā
translated: Therefore, at that time, wisdom should be cultivated.

original: yadā samapravṛtte dve api bhavato yuganaddhavāhibalīvardadvayavat tadānabhisaṃskāreṇaiva tāvat sthātavyaṃ yāvat kāyacittapīḍā na bhavet /
analyzed: yadā sama pravṛtte dve api bhavataḥ yuga naddha vāhi balīvarda dvaya vat tadā an abhisaṃskāreṇa eva tāvat sthātavyam yāvat kāya citta pīḍā na bhavet
translated: When the two are evenly engaged, like a pair of oxen pulling evenly, then one should remain without effort as long as there is no pain in body and mind.

original: saṃkṣepataḥ sarvasyaiva samādheḥ ṣaḍ doṣā bhavanti /🔽kausīdyam / ālambanasaṃpramoṣaḥ /🔽layaḥ /
analyzed: saṃkṣepataḥ sarvasya eva samādheḥ ṣaṭ doṣāḥ bhavanti  kausīdyam ālambana saṃpramoṣaḥ  layaḥ
translated: In brief, there are six faults for all samādhis.🔽Laziness. Forgetting the object.🔽Dullness.

analyzed: auddhatyam  anābhogaḥ
translated: Excitement.🔽Lack of application.

analyzed: ābhogaḥ ca iti
translated: Application.

analyzed: eṣām pratipakṣeṇa aṣṭau prahāṇa saṃskārāḥ bhāvanīyāḥ
translated: The eight eliminations are cultivated as antidotes to these.🔽Faith. Zeal.

analyzed: śraddhā chandaḥ
translated: Exertion.

analyzed: vyāyāmaḥ  prasrabdhiḥ  smṛtiḥ  saṃprajanyam
translated: Tranquility.🔽Mindfulness.🔽Awareness.

analyzed: cetanā
translated: Volition.

analyzed: upekṣā ca iti
translated: Equanimity.

analyzed: tatra ādyāḥ catvāraḥ kausīdya pratipakṣāḥ
translated: Among them, the first four are antidotes to laziness.

original: tathā hi samādhiguṇeṣvabhisaṃpratyayalakṣaṇayā śraddhayā yogino 'bhilāṣaḥ samutpadyate /
analyzed: tathā hi samādhi guṇeṣu abhisaṃpratyaya lakṣaṇayā śraddhayā yoginaḥ bhilāṣaḥ samutpadyate
translated: For thus, by faith characterized by conviction in the qualities of samādhi, the yogi's desire arises.

analyzed: tatas bhilāṣavān vīryam ārabhate
translated: Then, being desirous, he undertakes effort.

original: tato vīryārambhaṇāt kāyacittayoḥ karmaṇyatāṃ bhāvayati /🔽tataḥ prasrabdhakāyacetasaḥ Bhk
analyzed: tatas vīrya ārambhaṇāt kāya cittayoḥ karmaṇya tām bhāvayati 🔽tatas prasrabdha kāya cetasaḥ
translated: Then, due to undertaking effort, he cultivates workability of body and mind.🔽Then, with body and mind tranquil,

analyzed: kausīdyam vyāvartate
translated: Laziness is eliminated.

original: tataḥ śraddhādayaḥ kausīdyaprahāṇāya bhavanti tadartha te bhāvanīyāḥ /🔽smṛtirālambanasaṃpramoṣasya pratipakṣaḥ /
analyzed: tatas śraddhā ādayaḥ kausīdya prahāṇāya bhavanti tad artha te bhāvanīyāḥ  smṛtiḥ ālambana saṃpramoṣasya pratipakṣaḥ
translated: Therefore, faith and so on are for the elimination of laziness. They should be cultivated for that purpose.🔽Mindfulness is the antidote to the loss of the object.

analyzed: saṃprajanyam laya auddhatyayoḥ pratipakṣaḥ
translated: Clear comprehension is the antidote to slackness and excitedness.

analyzed: tayoḥ tena samupekṣya parivarjanāt
translated: Because by that, they are respectively abandoned and avoided.

original: layauddhatyāpraśamanakāle tu anābhogadoṣaḥ tatastatpratipakṣeṇa cetanā bhāvanīyā /
analyzed: laya auddhatyā praśamana kāle tu anābhoga doṣaḥ tatas tad pratipakṣeṇa cetanā bhāvanīyā
translated: But at the time of the pacification of slackness and excitedness, there is the fault of lack of attention. Therefore, volition should be cultivated as the antidote to that.

analyzed: laya auddhatya praśame sati
translated: When slackness and excitedness are pacified,

analyzed: yadā praśama bāhi cittam bhavet  tad ābhoga doṣaḥ
translated: if the mind becomes calm,🔽then there is the fault of attention.

analyzed: tasya pratipakṣaḥ tadānīm upekṣā bhāvanīyā
translated: The antidote to that should be cultivated at that time.

analyzed: yadi sama pravṛtte citte ābhogaḥ kriyate
translated: If attention is paid when the mind is functioning evenly,

analyzed: tadā cittam vikṣipyate
translated: then the mind is distracted.

original: līne 'pi citte sati yadyābhogo na kriyate /
analyzed: līne citte sati yadi ābhogaḥ na kriyate
translated: And if attention is not paid when the mind is slack,

analyzed: tadā vipaśyanā rahita tvāt
translated: then, being devoid of insight,

analyzed: andha puruṣa vat cittam līnam syāt  tasmāt līna cittam nigṛṇhīyāt
translated: the mind would be slack like a blind man.🔽Therefore, one should restrain the slack mind.

analyzed: uddhatam praśamayet
translated: One should pacify the excited mind.

analyzed: punar samā prāptam upekṣeta
translated: One should be indifferent to the mind that has again become concentrated.

original: tato yāvadiccha yogī tāvad anabhisaṃskāreṇaiva tattvaṃ bhāvayaṃstiṣṭhet /
analyzed: tatas yāvat iccha yogī tāvat an abhisaṃskāreṇa eva tattvam bhāvayan tiṣṭhet
translated: Then, the yogi should remain for as long as he wishes, contemplating reality without any deliberate effort.

original: satyāṃ tu kāyādipīḍāyāṃ punaḥ punarantarā sakalameva lokaṃ vyavalokyamāyājala candropamapratibhāsaṃ vata avataret /
analyzed: satyām tu kāya ādi pīḍāyām punar punar antarā sakalam eva lokam candra upama pratibhāsam vata avataret
translated: But when there is pain in the body and so on, he should again and again look at the entire world in between, and enter into the appearance that is like an illusion, a mirage, a dream, or the reflection of the moon in water.

original: tatha coktam avikalpapraveśe lokottareṇa jñānenākāśasamatalān sarvadharmānpaśyati /
analyzed: tathā ca uktam a vikalpa praveśe lokottareṇa jñānena ākāśa sama talān sarva dharmān paśyati
translated: And it is said in the Avicalpapraveśa: By supramundane knowledge, one sees all dharmas as equal to space.

analyzed: pṛṣṭha labdhena punar māyā marīci svapnaḥ daka candra upamān paśyati iti
translated: But by the knowledge attained afterwards, one sees them as like an illusion, a mirage, a dream, or the reflection of the moon in water.

analyzed: tat evam māyā upamam jagat avagamya
translated: Having thus understood the world to be like an illusion,

analyzed: sattveṣu mahā karuṇām ā mukhīkṛtya evam anuvicintayet
translated: and having brought great compassion towards beings to the fore, he should reflect in this way:

original: evaṃvidhaṃ dharmagāmbhoryam anavagacchanto 'mī bālabuddhaya ādiśānteṣveva dharmeṣu bhāvādisamāropaviparyastā vividhakarmakleśān upacinvanti
analyzed: evaṃvidham dharma gāmbhoryam an avagacchantaḥ bāla buddhayaḥ ādi śānteṣu eva dharmeṣu bhāva ādi samāropa viparyastāḥ vividha karma kleśān upacinvanti
translated: These foolish beings, not understanding the profundity of the Dharma in this way, are deluded about phenomena that are primordially peaceful, and accumulate various actions and afflictions.

analyzed: tatas saṃsāre paribhramanti
translated: Then they wander in cyclic existence.

original: tato 'haṃ kariṣyāmi yathaitān evaṃvidhaṃ dharmāgāmbhīryam avabodhayeyam iti /
analyzed: tatas ham kariṣyāmi yathā etān evaṃvidham dharma agāmbhīryam avabodhayeyam iti
translated: Therefore, I will do what is necessary to make them understand the profundity of the Dharma in this way.

original: tato viśramya punarapi tathaiva sarvadharmanirābhāsaṃ samādhimavataret /
analyzed: tatas viśramya punar api tathā eva sarva dharma nirābhāsam samādhim avataret
translated: Then, having rested, he should again enter the samādhi of the non-appearance of all dharmas in the same way.

analyzed: citta khede sati
translated: If the mind is tired,

analyzed: tathā eva viśramya punar avataret
translated: he should rest as before and enter again.

original: evam anena krameṇa ghaṭikām arthapraharam ekapraharaṃ vā yāvantaṃ kālaṃ śaknoti tāvantaṃ kālaṃ tiṣṭhet /🔽Bhk
analyzed: evam anena krameṇa ghaṭikām artha praharam eka praharam vā yāvantam kālam śaknoti tāvantam kālam tiṣṭhet  bhk
translated: In this way, by this method, he should stay for as long as he is able, for one ghaṭikā, one muhūrta, or one prahara.

original: tata icchayā samādheḥ utthātuṃ paryaṅkam abhittvaivam anuvicintayet /
analyzed: tatas icchayā samādheḥ utthātum paryaṅkam a bhittvā evam anuvicintayet
translated: Then, in order to rise from samādhi as he wishes, without breaking the cross-legged posture, he should contemplate in this way:

original: yadi nāmāmī dharmāḥ sarva eva paramārthato 'nutpannāstathāpi māyavat pratiniyatavividhahetupratyayasāmagrīvaśena vicitrā evāvicāraramaṇīyāḥ
analyzed: yadi nāma amī dharmāḥ sarve eva paramārthataḥ na utpannāḥ tathā api māya vat pratiniyata vividha hetu pratyaya sāmagrī vaśena vicitrāḥ evā avicāra ramaṇīyāḥ
translated: Although all these dharmas are ultimately unborn, still, like illusions, by the power of the collection of various determined causes and conditions, they are indeed various, delightful when not examined.

analyzed: tena nā uccheda dṛṣṭi prasaṅgaḥ
translated: Therefore, there is no danger of falling into the view of annihilation.

analyzed: na api apavāda antasya
translated: Nor is there the extreme of negation.

analyzed: yatas ca prajñayā vicāryamāṇāḥ na upalabhyante
translated: And because they are not perceived when examined by wisdom,

analyzed: tena na śāśvata dṛṣṭi prasaṅgaḥ nā api samāropa antasya
translated: there is no danger of falling into the view of permanence, nor is there the extreme of superimposition.

original: tatra ye prajñācakṣurvikalatayā viparyastamatayā ātmābhiniviṣṭā vividhāni karmāṇi kurvanti te saṃsāre paribhramanti /
analyzed: tatra ye prajñā cakṣuḥ vikala tayā viparyasta matayā ātma abhiniviṣṭāḥ vividhāni karmāṇi kurvanti te saṃsāre paribhramanti
translated: Among them, those who, due to the deficiency of the eye of wisdom and the perversity of their minds, are attached to the self and perform various actions, they wander in saṃsāra.

original: ye punarekāntena saṃsāravimukhā mahākāruṇyavikalatayā ca na sattvārthaṃ dānādipāramitāḥ
analyzed: ye punar ekāntena saṃsāra vimukhāḥ mahā kāruṇya vikala tayā ca na sattva artham dāna ādi pāramitāḥ
translated: But those who are completely averse to saṃsāra, and due to the absence of great compassion, do not fulfill the pāramitās of giving etc. for the sake of beings,

original: paripūrayanti ātmānaṃ damayanti te sattvā upāyavikalatayā śrāvakapratyekabuddhabodhau patanti /
analyzed: paripūrayanti ātmānam damayanti te sattvāḥ upāya vikala tayā śrāvaka pratyekabuddha bodhau patanti
translated: and tame themselves, those beings, due to the absence of skillful means, fall into the enlightenment of śrāvakas and pratyekabuddhas.

original: ye tu asvabhāvaṃ jagad avagamya mahākāruṇyabalena sakalajagadabhyuddharaṇakṛtaniścayā
analyzed: ye tu asvabhāvam jagat avagamya mahā kāruṇya balena sakala jagat abhyuddharaṇa kṛta niścayā
translated: But those who, having understood the world to be essenceless, with the power of great compassion, are determined to lift up the entire world,

original: māyākāravad aviparyastadhiyo vipulapuṇyajñānasaṃbhāraṃ samupāyanti te tathāgataṃ
analyzed: māyākāra vat aviparyasta dhiyaḥ vipula puṇya jñāna saṃbhāram samupāyanti te tathāgatam
translated: with minds free from error like a magician, accumulate the vast stores of merit and knowledge, they attain the state of a tathāgata,

original: padaṃ prāpyāsaṃsāramaśeṣasya jagataḥ sarvākāraṃ hitasukhāni saṃpādayantaḥ tiṣṭhanti /
analyzed: padam prāpya asaṃsāram aśeṣasya jagataḥ sarvākāram hita sukhāni saṃpādayantaḥ tiṣṭhanti
translated: and having attained that state, remaining until the end of saṃsāra, accomplishing in all ways the welfare and happiness of the entire world, they abide.

original: te ca jñānasambhārabalena samastakleśaprahāṇān na saṃsāre patanti sarvasattvāpekṣayā ca samupārjitavipulāprameyapuṇyasaṃbhāravaśena na
analyzed: te ca jñāna sambhāra balena samasta kleśa prahāṇāt na saṃsāre patanti sarva sattva apekṣayā ca samupārjita vipula aprameya puṇya saṃbhāra vaśena na
translated: And by the power of the accumulation of knowledge, through the abandonment of all afflictions, they do not fall into saṃsāra, and by the power of the vast and immeasurable accumulation of merit accumulated with regard to all beings, they

analyzed: sarva sattva upajīvyāḥ ca bhavanti
translated: become the support of all beings.

original: tasmān mayā sakalasattvahitasukhādhānārthināpratiṣṭhitanirvāṇam adhigantukāmena vipulapuṇyajñānasaṃbhāropārjane 'bhiyogaḥ sadā karaṇiyaḥ
analyzed: tasmāt mayā sakala sattva hita sukha ādhāna arthinā a pratiṣṭhita nirvāṇam adhigantu kāmena vipula puṇya jñāna saṃbhāra upārjane bhiyogaḥ sadā karaṇiyaḥ
translated: Therefore, I, who am desirous of accomplishing the welfare and happiness of all beings, who am desirous of attaining non-abiding nirvana, should always strive to accumulate the vast stores of merit and wisdom.

original: tathā coktam āryatathāgataguhyasutre jñānasambhāraḥ sarvakleśaprahāṇāya saṃvartate /
analyzed: tathā ca uktam ārya tathāgataguhyasutre jñāna sambhāraḥ sarva kleśa prahāṇāya saṃvartate
translated: And it is said in the noble Tathāgataguhya Sūtra: The store of wisdom leads to the abandonment of all afflictions.

analyzed: puṇya sambhāraḥ sarva sattva upajīvi tāyai saṃvartate
translated: The store of merit leads to being of benefit to all beings.

original: tasmāt tarhi bhagavan bodhisattvena mahāsattvena puṇyasambhāre jñānasaṃbhāre ca sarvadābhiyogaḥ karaṇīyaḥ iti /
analyzed: tasmāt tarhi bhagavan bodhisattvena mahāsattvena puṇya sambhāre jñāna saṃbhāre ca sarvadā abhiyogaḥ karaṇīyaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, Blessed One, a bodhisattva mahāsattva should always strive in the store of merit and the store of wisdom.

original: āryatathāgatotpattisaṃbhasūtre coktam sa khalu punareṣa tathāgatānāṃ Bhk
analyzed: ārya tathāgata utpatti saṃbha sūtre ca uktam sa khalu punar eṣa tathāgatānām
translated: And in the noble Tathāgatotpattisambhava Sūtra it is said: That, indeed, is the origin of the Tathāgatas,

analyzed: saṃbhavaḥ na ekena kāraṇena bhavati
translated: it does not happen by a single cause.

analyzed: tat kasya hetoḥ
translated: Why is that?

analyzed: samudāgataiḥ tāvat bho jinaputra aprameya śata sahasra daśa kāraṇaiḥ tathāgatāḥ samudāgacchanti
translated: O Son of the Victorious Ones, the Tathāgatas arise from the accumulation of immeasurable hundreds of thousands of causes.

analyzed: katamaiḥ daśabhiḥ yat uta aprameya puṇya jñāna sambhāra atṛpti samudāgama kāraṇena iti
translated: By which ten? Namely, by the cause of the accumulation of the store of merit and wisdom, which is insatiable, and so on at length.

original: āryavimalakīrtinirdeśe coktam śatapuṇyanirjātāḥ sarvakuśaladharmanirjātā apramāṇakuśalamūlakarmanirjātāḥ kāyāstathāgatasyeti vistaraḥ /
analyzed: ārya vimalakīrti nirdeśe ca uktam śata puṇya nirjātāḥ sarva kuśala dharma nirjātāḥ apramāṇa kuśala mūla karma nirjātāḥ kāyāḥ tathāgatasya iti vistaraḥ
translated: And it is said in the noble Vimalakirti Nirdesa: “The bodies of the Tathagatas are born of a hundred merits, born of all good dharmas, born of immeasurable roots of goodness and action.”

original: tad evaṃ kṛtvā śanaiḥ paryaṅkaṃ bhittvā daśadigvyavasthitān sarvabuddhabodhisattvān praṇipatya tebhyaśca pūjāstotropahāraṃ kṛtvāryabhadracaryādipraṇidhānaṃ
analyzed: tat evam kṛtvā śanais paryaṅkam bhittvā daśa diś vyavasthitān sarva buddha bodhisattvān praṇipatya tebhyaḥ ca pūjā stotra upahāram kṛtvā ārya bhadra caryā ādi praṇidhānam
translated: Having done this, one should slowly rise from the cross-legged position, bow to all the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas situated in the ten directions, make offerings and praises to them, and make the vow of noble Bhadracharya and so on.

analyzed: pranidadhīta
translated: One should make this vow.

analyzed: tatas śūnyatā karuṇā garbha anuttara saṃbodhi pariṇāmita sakala dāna ādi puṇya saṃbhāra upārjana abhiyuktaḥ bhavet
translated: Then, one should be devoted to accumulating all the merit of generosity and so on, which is dedicated to the highest enlightenment, the womb of emptiness and compassion.

analyzed: yaḥ tu manyate
translated: But one who thinks:

analyzed: citta vikalpa samutthāpita śubha aśubha karma vaśena sattvāḥ svarga ādi karma phalam anubhavantaḥ saṃsāre saṃsaranti
translated: Beings, by the power of good and bad actions produced by the imagination of the mind, experience the fruits of actions such as heaven and wander in cyclic existence.

original: ye punarna kiñciccintayanti nāpi kiñcit karma kurvanti te parimucyante saṃsārāt /
analyzed: ye punar na kiñcid cintayanti na api kiñcid karma kurvanti te parimucyante saṃsārāt
translated: But those who do not think anything and do not perform any action are liberated from cyclic existence.

analyzed: tasmāt na kiñcid cintayitavyam
translated: Therefore, one should not think anything.

analyzed: na api dāna ādi kuśala caryā kartavyā
translated: And one should not perform good conduct such as generosity.

analyzed: kevalam mūrkha janam adhikṛtya dāna ādi kuśala caryā nirdiṣṭā iti
translated: It is only with regard to foolish people that the practice of good conduct such as generosity is taught.

analyzed: tena sakala mahāyānam pratikṣiptam bhavet
translated: Therefore, the entire Mahāyāna would be rejected.

original: mahāyānamūlatvācca sarvayānānāṃ tatpratikṣepeṇa sarvam eva yānaṃ pratikṣiptaṃ syāt /
analyzed: mahāyāna mūla tvāt ca sarva yānānām tad pratikṣepeṇa sarvam eva yānam pratikṣiptam syāt
translated: And because the Mahāyāna is the root of all vehicles, by rejecting it, all vehicles would be rejected.

original: tathā hi 'na kiñciccintayitavyamiti' bruvata bhutapratyavekṣālakṣaṇā prajñā pratikṣiptā bhavet /
analyzed: tathā hi na kiñcid cintayitavyam iti bruvata bhuta pratyavekṣā lakṣaṇā prajñā pratikṣiptā bhavet
translated: For thus, by saying nothing should be thought, the wisdom characterized by the investigation of reality would be rejected.

original: bhūtapratyavekṣāmūlatvāt samyagjñānasya tatpratikṣepā llokottarāpi prajñā pratikṣiptā bhavet /
analyzed: bhūta pratyavekṣā mūla tvāt samyak jñānasya tad pratikṣepāḥ lokottarā api prajñā pratikṣiptā bhavet
translated: And because the investigation of reality is the root of right knowledge, by its rejection, even the supramundane wisdom would be rejected.

analyzed: tad pratikṣepāt sarva ākārajña tā pratikṣiptā bhavet
translated: By its rejection, the knowledge of all aspects would be rejected.

original: nāpi dānādicaryā kartavyeti vadatā copāyo dānādiḥ sphuṭatarameva pratikṣiptaḥ /
analyzed: nā api dāna ādi caryā kartavyā iti vadatā ca upāyaḥ dāna ādiḥ sphuṭataram eva pratikṣiptaḥ
translated: And by saying that the conduct such as generosity should not be done, the means such as generosity is clearly rejected.

original: etāvad eva ca saṃkṣiptaṃ mahāyānaṃ yaduta prajñopāyaśca /
analyzed: etāvat eva ca saṃkṣiptam mahāyānam yat uta prajñā upāyaḥ ca
translated: And this much alone is the concise Mahāyāna, namely wisdom and means.

original: yathoktam āryagayāśīrṣe dvāvimau bodhisattvānāṃ saṃkṣiptau mārgau /
analyzed: yathā uktam ārya gayāśīrṣe dvau imau bodhisattvānām saṃkṣiptau mārgau
translated: As it is said in the noble Gayāśīrṣa: These two are the concise paths for bodhisattvas.

analyzed: katamau dvau yat uta bhū
translated: Which two? Namely:

analyzed: prajñā ca upāyaḥ ca
translated: wisdom and means.

original: āryatathāgataguhyasūtre coktam imau ca prajñopāyau bodhisattvānāṃ sarvapāramitāsaṃgrahāya saṃvartete iti /
analyzed: ārya tathāgataguhyasūtre ca uktam imau ca prajñā upāyau bodhisattvānām sarva pāramitā saṃgrahāya saṃvartete iti
translated: And in the noble Tathāgataguhya Sūtra, these two, wisdom and means, are said to be for the gathering of all the perfections of the bodhisattvas.

original: tataśca mahāyānaṃ pratikṣipatā mahat karmāvaraṇaṃ kṛtaṃ syāt /
analyzed: tatas ca mahāyānam pratikṣipatā mahat karma āvaraṇam kṛtam syāt
translated: And so, one who rejects the Mahāyāna would be committing a great karmic obstruction.

analyzed: tasmāt mahāyānam pratikṣipataḥ
translated: Therefore, for one who rejects the Mahāyāna,

analyzed: alpa śrutasya
translated: who has little learning,

analyzed: ātma dṛṣṭim parāmṛśataḥ
translated: who clings to the view of self,

original: asyānupāsitavidvajjanasyānavadhāritatathāgatapravacananīteḥ svayaṃ vinaṣṭasya parān api nāśayato yuktyāgamadūṣitatvāt /
analyzed: asya anupāsita vidvas janasya anavadhārita tathāgata pravacana nīteḥ svayam vinaṣṭasya parān api nāśayataḥ yukti āgama dūṣita tvāt
translated: who has not attended to the wise, who has not ascertained the method of the Tathāgata's teaching, who is himself lost, who destroys others as well, because his words are tainted by reasoning and scripture,

original: viṣasaṃsṛṣṭavacanaṃ saviṣabhojanamiva ātmakāmena dhīmatā dūrata eva parihartavyam /
analyzed: viṣa saṃsṛṣṭa vacanam sa viṣa bhojanam iva ātma kāmena dhīmatā dūratas eva parihartavyam
translated: like poisoned food, a wise one who loves himself should avoid him from afar.

original: tathā hyanena bhūtapratyavekṣāṃ pratikṣipatā dharmapravicayākhyaṃ pradhānam eva bodhyaṅgaṃ pratikṣiptaṃ syāt /
analyzed: tathā hi anena bhūta pratyavekṣām pratikṣipatā dharma pravicaya ākhyam pradhānam eva bodhyaṅgam pratikṣiptam syāt
translated: For thus, by rejecting the investigation of reality, he would be rejecting the principal factor of the factors of enlightenment called discrimination of dharmas.

original: vinā ca mūtapratyavekṣayā yoginaḥ katham anādikālābhyastarūpādibhāvābhiniveśasya cittaṃ nirvikalpatāṃ praviśet /
analyzed: vinā ca mūta pratyavekṣayā yoginaḥ katham anādi kāla abhyasta rūpa ādi bhāva abhiniveśasya cittam nirvikalpa tām praviśet
translated: And without the investigation of reality, how could the yogi's mind enter into non-conceptuality, which has been habituated to the conception of form and so on since beginningless time?

analyzed: sarva dharmeṣu a smṛti a manasikāreṇa praviśati iti ced
translated: If it is said that one enters [the absence of conceptualization] by not remembering and not attending to all phenomena,

analyzed: tat ayuktam
translated: that is not correct.

original: na hi vinā bhūtapratyavekṣayānubhūyamāneṣvapi sarvadharmeṣvasmṛtiramanasikāro vā śakyate kartum /
analyzed: na hi vinā bhūta pratyavekṣayā anubhūyamāneṣu api sarva dharmeṣu asmṛtiḥ amanasikāraḥ vā śakyate kartum
translated: For without investigating the elements, it is not possible to not remember or not attend to all phenomena that are being experienced.

original: yadi ca nāmāmī dharmā mayāsmartavyā nāpi manasikartavyā ityevaṃ bhāvayannasmṛtimanasikārau teṣu bhāvayet tadā sutarām eva tena te smṛtā manasikṛtāśca 🔽syuḥ /
analyzed: yadi ca nāma amī dharmāḥ mayā a smartavyāḥ na api manasikartavyāḥ iti evam bhāvayan a smṛti manasikārau teṣu bhāvayet tadā sutarām eva tena te smṛtāḥ manasikṛtāḥ ca  syuḥ
translated: And if, thinking I should not remember these phenomena, nor should I attend to them, one cultivates non-memory and non-attention towards them, then they would be remembered and attended to by him all the more.

analyzed: atha smṛti manasikāra abhāva mātram asmṛti amanasikārau abhipretau
translated: If, on the other hand, non-memory and non-attention are intended to mean merely the absence of memory and attention,

original: tadā tayorabhāvaḥ kena prakāreṇa bhavatīti etad eva vicāryate /
analyzed: tadā tayoḥ abhāvaḥ kena prakāreṇa bhavati iti etat eva vicāryate
translated: then how can their absence occur? This is precisely what is being considered.

original: na cābhāvaḥ kāraṇaṃ yuktam /🔽yena tato nirnimittāmanasikārāt nirvikalpatā bhavet /
analyzed: na ca abhāvaḥ kāraṇam yuktam  yena tatas nirnimitta amanasikārāt nirvikalpa tā bhavet
translated: And absence is not a suitable cause.🔽By which [absence], non-conceptuality would occur from that non-attention without a cause.

analyzed: tanmātrataḥ vikalpa tāyām saṃmurcchitasya api smṛti manasikāra abhāvāt nirvikalpa tā praveśa prasaṅgaḥ
translated: In the case of non-conceptuality from that alone, even a person who has fainted would have the absence of memory and attention, and it would follow that he has entered non-conceptuality.

original: na ca bhūtapratyavekṣāṃ vinānya upāyo 'sti yena prakāreṇāsmṛtyamanasikārau kuryāt /
analyzed: na ca bhūta pratyavekṣām vinā anyaḥ upāyaḥ sti yena prakāreṇa asmṛti amanasikārau kuryāt
translated: And without the investigation of the elements, there is no other means by which one could perform non-mindfulness and non-attention.

analyzed: sati api ca a smṛti a manasikāra sambhave
translated: And even if non-mindfulness and non-attention were possible,

original: vinā bhūtapratyavekṣayā niḥsvabhāvatā dharmāṇāṃ katham avagatā bhavet /
analyzed: vinā bhūta pratyavekṣayā niḥsvabhāva tā dharmāṇām katham avagatā bhavet
translated: how could the absence of intrinsic nature of dharmas be understood without the investigation of the elements?

original: na hi svabhāvata evaṃ dharmāḥ Bhk
analyzed: na hi svabhāvataḥ evam dharmāḥ
translated: For dharmas are not empty of intrinsic nature

original: śūnyāḥ sthitā ityevaṃ vinā tatpratyavekṣayā tacchūnyatāprativedho bhavet /
analyzed: śūnyāḥ sthitāḥ iti evam vinā tad pratyavekṣayā tad śūnyatā prativedhaḥ bhavet
translated: in this way, without that investigation, the penetration of their emptiness would not occur.

original: nāpi vinā śūnyatāprativedhena āvaraṇaprahāṇaṃ saṃbhavati sarvatra sarveṣāṃ muktiprasaṅgāt /
analyzed: nā api vinā śūnyatā prativedhena āvaraṇa prahāṇam saṃbhavati sarvatra sarveṣām mukti prasaṅgāt
translated: And without the penetration of emptiness, the abandonment of obscurations is not possible, because everyone everywhere would be liberated.

original: kiṃ ca tasya yogino yadi sarvadharmeṣu muṣitasmṛtitayā mūḍhatayā vā smṛtimanasikārau na pravartete /
analyzed: kim ca tasya yoginaḥ yadi sarva dharmeṣu muṣita smṛti tayā mūḍha tayā vā smṛti manasikārau na pravartete
translated: Moreover, if for that yogin mindfulness and attention do not occur due to forgetfulness or delusion regarding all dharmas,

analyzed: tadā atyanta mūḍhaḥ katham asau yogī bhavet
translated: how could he be a yogin at all, being utterly deluded?

original: vinā ca bhūtapratyavekṣayā tatrāsmṛtim amanasikāraṃ cābhyastatā moha evābhyasto bhavet /
analyzed: vinā ca bhūta pratyavekṣayā tatra asmṛtim amanasikāram ca abhyasta tā mohaḥ evā abhyastaḥ bhavet
translated: And without the investigation of the elements, the practice of non-mindfulness and non-attention there would be the practice of delusion alone.

analyzed: tatas eva samyak jñāna ālokaḥ dūrīkṛtaḥ syāt
translated: From that alone, the light of right knowledge would be removed.

analyzed: atha asau na muṣita smṛtiḥ na api mūḍhaḥ
translated: But if he is not forgetful and not deluded,

original: tadā kathaṃ tatrāsmaraṇam amanasikāraṃ kartu śaknuyād vinā bhūtapratyavekṣayā /🔽na hi smaranneva na smarati /
analyzed: tadā katham tatra asmaraṇam amanasikāram kartu śaknuyāt vinā bhūta pratyavekṣayā  na hi smaran eva na smarati
translated: Then, how can one be able to make non-remembrance and non-attention there without investigating the elements?🔽For it is not reasonable to say that one does not remember while remembering,

original: paśyan eva na paśyatīti yuktam abhidhātum /
analyzed: paśyan eva na paśyati iti yuktam abhidhātum
translated: or that one does not see while seeing.

analyzed: a smṛti a manasikāra abhyāsāt ca katham pūrva nivāsa anusmṛti ādi buddha dharma udayaḥ bhavet
translated: And how could the arising of the Buddha's qualities such as recollection of past lives come from the practice of non-remembrance and non-attention?

analyzed: virodhāt
translated: Because of contradiction.

original: na hyuṣṇaviruddhaṃ śītam āsevamānasya uṣṇasparśasaṃvedanaṃ bhavet /
analyzed: na hi uṣṇa viruddham śītam āsevamānasya uṣṇa sparśa saṃvedanam bhavet
translated: For one who is cultivating what is opposed to heat, the experience of a hot touch would not occur.

original: kiṃ ca samādhisamāpannasya yogino yadi manovijñānam asti /
analyzed: kim ca samādhi samāpannasya yoginaḥ yadi manaḥ vijñānam asti
translated: Moreover, if the yogi who has entered meditative concentration has mental consciousness,

analyzed: tadā avaśyam tena kiṃcid ālambayitavyam
translated: then he must necessarily take something as an object.

original: na hi pṛthagjanānāṃ sahasā nirālambanaṃ jñānaṃ bhavet /
analyzed: na hi pṛthagjanānām sahasā nirālambanam jñānam bhavet
translated: For the knowledge of ordinary people cannot suddenly be without an object.

original: atha nāsti / tadā kathaṃ niḥsvabhāvatā dharmāṇāmavagatā bhavet /
analyzed: atha nā asti tadā katham niḥsvabhāva tā dharmāṇām avagatā bhavet
translated: If not, then how could the essencelessness of phenomena be understood?

analyzed: kena ca pratipakṣeṇa kleśa āvaraṇam prahīyate
translated: And by what antidote is the obscuration of afflictions abandoned?

original: na ca caturthadhyānālābhinaḥ pṛthagjanasya cittanirodhaḥ saṃbhavati /
analyzed: na ca caturtha dhyāna alābhinaḥ pṛthagjanasya citta nirodhaḥ saṃbhavati
translated: And for an ordinary person who has not attained the fourth meditation, the cessation of mind is not possible.

original: tasmāt saddharme yāvasmṛtyamanasikārau paṭhitau tau bhūtapratyavekṣāpūrvākau draṣṭavyau /
analyzed: tasmāt saddharme yau asmṛtya manasikārau paṭhitau tau bhūta pratyavekṣā pūrvākau draṣṭavyau
translated: Therefore, in the true Dharma, mindfulness and attention are recited. They should be seen as preceded by the investigation of reality.

analyzed: asmāt bhūta pratyavekṣayā asmṛtiḥ manasikāraḥ ca śakyate kartum na anyathā
translated: For from this investigation of reality, mindfulness and attention can be made, not otherwise.

original: tathā hi yadā nirūpayan samyakprajñayā yogī kālatraye paramārthataḥ samutpannaṃ na kaṃcid dharma paśyati /
analyzed: tathā hi yadā nirūpayan samyak prajñayā yogī kāla traye paramārthataḥ samutpannam na kaṃcid dharma paśyati
translated: For when the yogi, investigating with right wisdom, does not see any dharma arisen in the ultimate sense in the three times,

analyzed: tadā tatra katham smṛti manasikārau kuryāt
translated: then how can he make mindfulness and attention towards it?

original: yo hi kālatraye 'pyasattvān nānubhūtaḥ paramārthataḥ sa kathaṃ smaryeta /
analyzed: yaḥ hi kāla traye pi asattvāt na anubhūtaḥ paramārthataḥ sa katham smaryeta
translated: For what is not experienced in the three times as non-existent in the ultimate sense, how can that be remembered?

analyzed: manasi vā kriyeta
translated: Or how can it be made the object of the mind?

original: tato 'sau sarvaprapañcopaśamaṃ nirvikalpaṃ jñānaṃ praviṣṭo bhavet /
analyzed: sarva prapañca upaśamam nirvikalpam jñānam praviṣṭaḥ bhavet
translated: Therefore, he would have entered into the knowledge free from conceptualization, the cessation of all conceptual proliferation.

original: tatpraveśācca śūnyatāṃ pratividhyati tatprativedhācca prahīṇasakalakudṛṣṭijālo bhavati /🔽Bhk
analyzed: tad praveśāt ca śūnyatām pratividhyati tad prativedhāt ca prahīṇa sakala kudṛṣṭi jālaḥ bhavati  bhk
translated: And from that entry, he penetrates emptiness. And from that penetration, he becomes one whose net of all bad views is destroyed.

analyzed: upāya yuktaḥ prajñā sevanataḥ ca samyak saṃvṛti paramārtha satya kuśalaḥ bhavati
translated: And from the cultivation of wisdom in union with means, he becomes one who is well-versed in the conventional and ultimate truths.

analyzed: atas na āvaraṇa jñāna lābhāt sarvān eva buddha dharmān adhigacchati
translated: Therefore, from the attainment of unobstructed knowledge, he attains all the Buddha-dharmas.

original: tasmānna vinā bhūtapratyavekṣayā samyagjñānodayo nāpi kleśāvaraṇaprahāṇām /
analyzed: tasmāt na vinā bhūta pratyavekṣayā samyak jñāna udayaḥ nā api kleśa āvaraṇa prahāṇām
translated: Therefore, without investigating the elements, there is no arising of right knowledge, nor the abandonment of the afflictive obstructions.

original: tathā coktaṃ mañjuśrīvikurvitasūtre kathaṃ dārike bodhisattvo vijitasaṃgrāmo bhavati /
analyzed: tathā ca uktam mañjuśrī vikurvita sūtre katham dārike bodhisattvaḥ vijita saṃgrāmaḥ bhavati
translated: And thus it is said in the Mañjuśrīvikurvāṇasūtra: How, young lady, does a bodhisattva become one who has conquered the enemy?

original: āha / yo mañjuśrīḥ vicāya vicāya sarvadharmān nopalabhate iti /
analyzed: āha yaḥ mañjuśrīḥ vicāya vicāya sarva dharmān na upalabhate iti
translated: She said: Mañjuśrī, one who investigates and investigates all phenomena and does not apprehend them.

analyzed: tasmāt visphārita jñāna cakṣuḥ prajñā śastreṇa kleśa arīn nirjitya
translated: Therefore, with the eye of expanded knowledge, having conquered the enemies of the afflictions with the weapon of wisdom,

analyzed: nirbhayaḥ viharan yogī
translated: the yogi dwells fearlessly.

analyzed: na tu kātara puruṣaḥ iva vinimīlita akṣaḥ
translated: But not like a timid man with eyes closed.

analyzed: ārya samādhirāje pi uktam
translated: It is also said in the noble Samādhirāja:

original: nairātmyadharmān yadi pratyevekṣate tān pratyavekṣya yadi bhāvayet /
analyzed: nairātmya dharmān yadi pratyevekṣate tān pratyavekṣya yadi bhāvayet
translated: If one investigates those selfless dharmas, having investigated them, if one cultivates them,

original: sa hetu nirvāṇapahalasya prāptaye yo 'nyaheturna sa bhoti śāntaye // iti /
analyzed: prāptaye yaḥ śāntaye
translated: That is the cause for attaining the fruit of nirvāṇa. Any other cause is not for peace.

original: sutrasamuccaye coktam ātmanā vipaśyanāyogam anuyukto viharati parāṃśca vipaśyanāyāṃ nābhiyojayatīti mārakarmeti /
analyzed: sutra samuccaye ca uktam ātmanā vipaśyanā yogam anuyuktaḥ viharati parān ca vipaśyanāyām na abhiyojayati iti māra karma iti
translated: And in the Sūtrasamuccaya it is said: Dwelling engaged in the yoga of insight oneself, but not applying others to insight, is the work of Māra.

analyzed: vipaśyanā ca bhūta pratyavekṣā svabhāvā ārya ratna megha sandhi nirmocana ādau
translated: And insight has the nature of investigating the real, as is taught in the noble Cloud of Jewels, the Liberation of Saṃdhi, and so on.

original: āryaratnameghe ca vipaśyanāṃ nirūpayato niḥsvabhāvatāprativedhad animittapraveśa uktaḥ /
analyzed: ārya ratnameghe ca vipaśyanām nirūpayataḥ niḥsvabhāva tā prativedhat animitta praveśaḥ uktaḥ
translated: And in the noble Cloud of Jewels, when insight is examined, the entry into signlessness is taught by penetrating the lack of inherent nature.

analyzed: ārya laṅkāvatāre ca uktam yasmāt
translated: And it is said in the noble Laṅkāvatāra:

analyzed: mahāmate
translated: Mahāmati,

analyzed: buddhayā vicāryamāṇānām sva sāmānya lakṣaṇam bhāvānām na avadhāryate
translated: when things are being examined with the intellect, the specific and general characteristics are not ascertained.

analyzed: tena ucyante niḥsvabhāvāḥ sarva dharmāḥ iti
translated: Therefore, it is said that all dharmas are without inherent nature.

original: tatra tatra sūtre yā bhagavatā nānāprakārā pratyavekṣā nirdiṣṭā sā virudhyate /
analyzed: tatra tatra sūtre yā bhagavatā nānā prakārā pratyavekṣā nirdiṣṭā sā virudhyate
translated: The various kinds of investigation taught by the Blessed One in this and that sūtra are contradicted.

analyzed: yadi bhūta pratyavekṣā na kartavyā
translated: If the investigation of the real should not be done.

original: tasmād evaṃ yuktaṃ vaktuṃ vayam alpaprajñā alpavīryāścana śaknumo bāhuśrutyaṃ paryeṣitumiti /🔽na hi tatpratikṣepo yukto bhagavatā Bhk
analyzed: tasmāt evam yuktam vaktum vayam alpa prajñāḥ alpa vīryāḥ cana śaknumaḥ bāhuśrutyam paryeṣitum iti  na hi tad pratikṣepaḥ yuktaḥ bhagavatā
translated: Therefore, it is appropriate to say this: We are of little wisdom and little energy, and we are not able to seek much learning.

analyzed: bahudhā bāhuśrutyasya varṇita tvāt
translated: For it is not right to reject that, because the Blessed One has praised much learning in many ways.

original: tat punarbrahmaparipṛcchāyām uktam ye tvacintyeṣu dharmeṣu cintanaviprayuktāḥ teṣām ayoniśa iti /
analyzed: tat punar brahmaparipṛcchāyām uktam ye tu acintyeṣu dharmeṣu cintana viprayuktāḥ teṣām ayoniśas iti
translated: And that is said in the Brahmaparipṛcchā: But for those who are detached from thinking about inconceivable dharmas, that is not proper mental application.

original: tatrāpi ye paramārthato 'nutpannānāṃ dharmāṇām utpādaṃ parikalpyānityaduḥkhadirūpeṇa śrāvakādivaccintāṃ prakurvanti /
analyzed: tatra api ye paramārthataḥ dharmāṇām utpādam parikalpya anitya duḥkha di rūpeṇa śrāvaka ādi vat cintām prakurvanti
translated: Even there, those who imagine the arising of dharmas that are ultimately unborn, and engage in thought like the śrāvakas and others, considering them to be impermanent, suffering, and so on,

original: teṣāṃ samāropāpavādāntena cintāṃ pravartayatām ayoniśaḥ tad bhavatīti tatpratiṣedhāya yad uktaṃ na bhūtapratyavekṣāyāḥ sa pratiṣedhaḥ tasyāḥ
analyzed: teṣām samāropa apavāda antena cintām pravartayatām ayoniśas tat bhavati iti tad pratiṣedhāya yat uktam na bhūta pratyavekṣāyāḥ sa pratiṣedhaḥ tasyāḥ
translated: for them, who engage in thought with the extremes of superimposition and denial, that [thought] is improper. In order to refute that, what was said is not a refutation of the investigation of the elements,

original: sarvasūtreṣvanujñānāt /🔽tathā ca tatraiva brahmaparipṛcchāyām uktam cittaśūro bodhisattva āhayaścittena sarvadharmāścintayati tatra cākṣato 'nupahataḥ sa tenocyate
analyzed: sarva sūtreṣu anujñānāt  tathā ca tatra eva brahmaparipṛcchāyām uktam cittaśūraḥ bodhisattvaḥ āha yaḥ cittena sarva dharmāḥ cintayati tatra ca akṣataḥ n upahataḥ sa tena ucyate
translated: because it is approved in all sūtras.

analyzed: bodhisattvaḥ iti
translated: And in that very [Brahma's Net Sūtra], it is said in the Brahma's Net Chapter: The bodhisattva Mind-Hero said: One who thinks about all dharmas with the mind, and is not injured or harmed there, is called a bodhisattva.

analyzed: tatra eva uktam katham vīryavantaḥ bhavanti
translated: In that very [sūtra], it is said: How do they become endowed with vigor?

original: yada sarvajñatācittaṃ vicīyamānānopalabhante iti /🔽punaḥ tatraivoktam matimantaśca te bhaviṣyanti yoniśo dharmān pratyavekṣaṇatayeti /
analyzed: sarvajña tā cittam iti  punar tatra eva uktam matimantaḥ ca te bhaviṣyanti yoniśas dharmān pratyavekṣaṇa tayā iti
translated: When they do not apprehend the mind of omniscience, even when investigating.🔽Again, in that very [sūtra], it is said: They will have wisdom, by investigating the dharmas in accordance with reality.

original: punaḥ tatraivoktam pravicinvanti te dharmān yathā māyāmarīciketi /
analyzed: punar tatra eva uktam pravicinvanti te dharmān yathā māyā marīcikā iti
translated: Again, in that very [sūtra], it is said: They investigate the dharmas, like an illusion or a mirage.

analyzed: tat evam yatra yatra acintya ādi prapañcaḥ śrūyate
translated: Thus, wherever the elaboration of the inconceivable, etc. is heard,

original: tatra tatra śrutacintāmātreṇaiva tattvādhigamaṃ ye manyante /
analyzed: tatra tatra śruta cintā mātreṇa eva tattva adhigamam ye manyante
translated: those who think that the realization of reality is only through hearing and reflection,

analyzed: teṣām abhimāna pratiṣedhena pratyātma vedanīya tvam dharmāṇām pratipādayate
translated: for them, in order to refute their conceit, it teaches that dharmas are to be known by each one's own experience.

analyzed: ayoniśas ca citta pratiṣedhaḥ kriyate iti boddhavyam
translated: And it should be understood that the prohibition is against improper mental activity.

analyzed: na bhūta pratyavekṣāyāḥ pratiṣedhaḥ
translated: It is not a prohibition against investigating the elements.

analyzed: anyathā bahutaram yukti āgama viruddham syāt
translated: Otherwise, it would contradict logic and scripture in many more ways,

analyzed: yathā uktam prāk
translated: as was said before.

original: kiñca yad eva śrutacintāmayyā prajñayā viditaṃ tad eva bhāvanāmayyā prajñayā bhāvanīyaṃ nānyat /
analyzed: kiñca yat eva śruta cintā mayyā prajñayā viditam tat eva bhāvanā mayyā prajñayā bhāvanīyam na anyat
translated: Moreover, only what is known through the wisdom of hearing and reflection should be cultivated through the wisdom of meditation, not anything else.

analyzed: saṃdiṣṭa dhāvana bhūmi aśva dhāvana vat
translated: Like a well-trained horse and a well-trained chariot.

analyzed: tasmāt bhūta pratyavekṣā kartavyā
translated: Therefore, the investigation of the elements should be done.

original: yadi nāmāsau vikalpasvabhāvātathāpi yoniśo manasikārasvabhāvatvāt tato bhūta nirvikalpajñānodaya iti kṛtvā tajjñānārthinā sā sevanīyā /
analyzed: yadi nāma asau yoniśas manasikāra svabhāva tvāt tatas bhūta nirvikalpa jñāna udayaḥ iti kṛtvā tad jñāna arthinā sā sevanīyā
translated: Even though it has the nature of conceptualization, still, because it has the nature of proper mental attention, the non-conceptual knowledge of reality arises from it. Therefore, one who seeks that knowledge should cultivate it.

analyzed: nirvikalpe ca bhuta jñāna agnau bhk  samutpanne
translated: And when the fire of non-conceptual knowledge of reality🔽arises,

analyzed: sati
translated: when it exists,

original: kāṣṭhadvayanigharṣasaṃjātavanhinā tatkāṣṭhadvayadāhavat sāpi paścāt tenaiva dahyata evetyuktam āryaratnakūṭe /
analyzed: kāṣṭha dvaya nigharṣa saṃjāta vanhinā tat kāṣṭha dvaya dāha vat sā api paścāt tena eva dahyate eva iti uktam ārya ratnakūṭe
translated: It is said in the noble Ratnakūṭa that she is later burned by that very [fire] that arises from the friction of the two pieces of wood, just as the two pieces of wood are burned by the fire that arises from their friction.

original: yaccāpyucyate na kiṃcit kuśalādikarma kartavyam iti /
analyzed: yat ca api ucyate na kiṃcid kuśala ādi karma kartavyam iti
translated: And what is said, that no action whatsoever, whether wholesome or otherwise, should be done,

original: tatraivaivaṃ vadatā karmakṣayān muktirityājīvaka vādābhyupagamo bhavet /
analyzed: tatra evā evam vadatā karma kṣayāt muktiḥ iti ājīvaka vāda abhyupagamaḥ bhavet
translated: there, by one who speaks thus, it would be an acceptance of the Ājīvika doctrine that liberation comes from the exhaustion of action.

analyzed: na hi bhagavat pravacane karma kṣayāt muktiḥ iṣyate
translated: For in the Blessed One's teaching, liberation is not considered to come from the exhaustion of action.

analyzed: kim tarhi kleśa kṣayāt
translated: What then? From the exhaustion of afflictions.

original: anādikālopacittasya hi karmaṇo na śakyate kṣayaḥ kartu tasyānantatvāt /
analyzed: anādi kāla upacittasya hi karmaṇaḥ na śakyate kṣayaḥ kartu tasya ananta tvāt
translated: For the exhaustion of action accumulated since beginningless time is not possible, because it is infinite.

original: apāyādiṣu ca tatphalaṃ bhuñjānasyāparasyāpi karmaṇaḥ prasūteḥ kleśeṣu cāvikaleṣu tatkaraṇatayā sthiteṣu karmaṇo niroddhum aśakyatvāt /
analyzed: apāya ādiṣu ca tad phalam bhuñjānasya aparasya api karmaṇaḥ prasūteḥ kleśeṣu ca avikaleṣu tad karaṇa tayā sthiteṣu karmaṇaḥ niroddhum aśakya tvāt
translated: And while one is experiencing the fruits of that [action] in the lower realms and so on, because another action is produced, and because the afflictions remain intact and present as the instruments [of action], action cannot be stopped.

original: pradīpānirodhe tatprabhāyā anirodhavat /🔽na cāpi tasya vipaśyanāpavādinaḥ kleśakṣayaḥ saṃbhavatītyukta prāk /
analyzed: pradīpa anirodhe tad prabhāyāḥ anirodha vat  na ca api tasya vipaśyanā apavādinaḥ kleśa kṣayaḥ saṃbhavati iti ukta prāk
translated: Just as the light [of a lamp] cannot be stopped without stopping the lamp.🔽And for him who denies insight, the exhaustion of afflictions is not possible, as was said before.

analyzed: atha kleśa kṣaya artha vipaśyanā sevanīyā iti manyate
translated: If he thinks that insight should be cultivated for the purpose of exhausting the afflictions,

original: tadā kleśakṣayād eva muktiḥ sidhyatīti karmakṣaye tarhi vyarthaḥ śramaḥ /
analyzed: tadā kleśa kṣayāt eva muktiḥ sidhyati iti karma kṣaye tarhi vyarthaḥ śramaḥ
translated: Then, liberation is accomplished just by the destruction of afflictions, so effort to destroy karma is pointless.

analyzed: akuśala karma na kartavyam iti yuktam etat
translated: It is right that unwholesome karma should not be done.

analyzed: kuśalam tu kim iti pratiṣidhyate
translated: But why is wholesome [karma] prohibited?

analyzed: saṃsāra āvāhaka tvāt pratiṣidhyate iti ced
translated: If it is said that it is prohibited because it causes the continuation of samsara,

analyzed: tat ayuktam
translated: that is not correct.

original: yad eva ātmādiviparyāsasamutthāpitam kuśalaṃ tad eva saṃsārāvāhakaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: yat eva ātma ādi viparyāsa samutthāpitam kuśalam tat eva saṃsāra āvāhakam bhavati
translated: Only that wholesome [karma] produced by the error of self, etc. causes the continuation of samsara.

original: na tu bodhisattvānāṃ mahākaruṇāsamutthāpitam anuttarasaṃbodhipariṇāmitamapi /🔽tathā āryadaśabhūmake eta eva daśakuśalakarmapathāḥ pariṇāmanādipariśuddhiviśeṣeṇa śrāvakapratyekabuddhabodhisattvabuddhatvavāhakā bhavantīti
analyzed: na tu bodhisattvānām mahā karuṇā samutthāpitam anuttara saṃbodhi pariṇāmitam api  tathā ārya daśabhūmake ete eva daśa kuśala karma pathāḥ pariṇāmana ādi pariśuddhi viśeṣeṇa śrāvaka pratyekabuddha bodhisattva buddhatva vāhakāḥ bhavanti iti
translated: But not that produced by the great compassion of the bodhisattvas, dedicated to unsurpassed enlightenment.

analyzed: nirdiṣṭam
translated: Thus, in the noble Dashabhumika, it is shown that these very ten wholesome actions, by the special purity of dedication, etc., become the cause of the states of the disciples, solitary realizers, bodhisattvas, and Buddhas.

original: āryaratnakūṭe ca /🔽sarvamahānadīnāṃ mahāsamudre praviṣṭānāṃ payaḥ skandhavad bodhisattvānāṃ nānāmukhopacitaṃ kuśalamūlaṃ sarvajñatāpariṇāmitaṃ sarvajñataikarasaṃ
analyzed: ārya ratnakūṭe ca  sarva mahā nadīnām mahā samudre praviṣṭānām payaḥ skandhavat bodhisattvānām nānā mukha upacitam kuśala mūlam sarvajña tā pariṇāmitam sarvajña tā ekarasam
translated: And in the noble Ratnakūṭa,🔽it is said that the wholesome roots accumulated by the bodhisattvas through various means, when dedicated to omniscience, become of the same taste as omniscience,

analyzed: bhavati iti varṇitam 🔽bhk
translated: like the mass of water of all the great rivers that flow into the great ocean.

original: yā ca buddhabodhisattvānāṃ rūpakāyakṣetrapariśuddhiḥ prabhāparivāramahābhogatādisaṃpattiḥ dānādipuṇyasambhāraphalasattvena tatra tatra sūtre
analyzed: yā ca buddha bodhisattvānām rūpa kāya kṣetra pariśuddhiḥ prabhā parivāra mahā bhoga tā ādi saṃpattiḥ dāna ādi puṇya sambhāra phala sattvena tatra tatra sūtre
translated: And the purification of the form body and buddha-field of the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas, the perfection of great radiance, retinue, and enjoyments, etc., which are described here and there in the sutras by the Blessed One as the fruit of the accumulation of merit such as generosity, etc.,

analyzed: varṇitā bhagavatā sā api virudhyate
translated: that also is contradicted.

analyzed: kuśala caryā pratiṣedhe ca prātimokṣa saṃvara ādiḥ api pratikṣiptaḥ syāt
translated: And in the prohibition of wholesome conduct, the Prātimokṣa restraint, etc., would also be rejected.

analyzed: tatas vyartham eva tasya śiraḥ muṇḍita kāṣāya dhāraṇa ādi prasajyeta
translated: Then it would absurdly follow that for him, shaving the head, wearing saffron robes, etc., would be pointless.

original: kuśalakarmābhisaṃskāravaimukhye ca sati saṃsāravaimukhyaṃ sattvārthakriyāvaimukhyaṃ ca sevitaṃ bhavet /
analyzed: kuśala karma abhisaṃskāra vaimukhye ca sati saṃsāra vaimukhyam sattva arthakriyā vaimukhyam ca sevitam bhavet
translated: And if he were averse to the performance of wholesome actions, he would be serving aversion to saṃsāra and aversion to benefiting beings.

analyzed: tatas bodhiḥ tasya dūre bhavet
translated: Then enlightenment would be far away for him.

original: uktaṃ hyāryaṃsaṃdhinirmocane ekāntasattvārthavimukhasya ekāntasaṃskārā bhisaṃskāravimukhasya nānuttarāsamyaksaṃbodhiruktā mayeti /
analyzed: uktam hi āryam saṃdhi nirmocane ekānta sattva artha vimukhasya ekānta saṃskāra abhisaṃskāra vimukhasya na anuttarā samyaksaṃbodhiḥ uktā mayā iti
translated: For it is said in the noble Sandhinirmocana Sūtra: I have not taught that one who is averse to benefiting beings and averse to the performance of formations attains the highest complete enlightenment.

original: āryopāliparipṛcchādau ca saṃsāre vaimukhyaṃ bodhisattvānāṃ paradauḥśīlyamiti varṇitam /
analyzed: ārya upāli paripṛcchā ādau ca saṃsāre vaimukhyam bodhisattvānām para dauḥśīlyam iti varṇitam
translated: And in the noble Upāliparipṛcchā, etc., aversion to saṃsāra is described as the worst immorality for bodhisattvas.

analyzed: saṃsāra parigrahaḥ tu paramam śīlam
translated: But embracing saṃsāra is the highest morality.

original: uktam āryavimalakīrtinirdeśe ca upāyād bhavati saṃsāragamanaṃ bodhisattvānāṃ mokṣaḥ /🔽upāyarahitā ca prajñā bandhaḥ /
analyzed: uktam ārya vimalakīrti nirdeśe ca upāyāt bhavati saṃsāra gamanam bodhisattvānām mokṣaḥ  upāya rahitā ca prajñā bandhaḥ
translated: And it is said in the noble Vimalakīrti-nirdeśa: “For bodhisattvas, going in saṃsāra is liberation through skillful means.🔽Wisdom devoid of skillful means is bondage.

analyzed: prajñā rahitaḥ ca upāyaḥ bandhaḥ  prajñā sahitaḥ upāyaḥ mokṣaḥ
translated: Skillful means devoid of wisdom is bondage.🔽Skillful means accompanied by wisdom is liberation.

analyzed: upāya sahitā prajñā mokṣaḥ iti varṇitam
translated: Wisdom accompanied by skillful means is liberation.”

original: āryagaganagañje uktam saṃsāraparikhedo bodhisattvānāṃ mārakarma iti /
analyzed: ārya gaganagañje uktam saṃsāra parikhedaḥ bodhisattvānām māra karma iti
translated: It is said in the noble Gaganagañja: “Discouragement in saṃsāra is a deed of Māra for bodhisattvas.”

original: sūtrasamuccaye ca asaṃskṛtaṃ ca pratyavekṣate saṃskṛtaiśca kuśalaiḥ parikhidyata iti mārakarma iti /
analyzed: sūtra samuccaye ca a saṃskṛtam ca pratyavekṣate saṃskṛtaiḥ ca kuśalaiḥ parikhidyate iti māra karma iti
translated: And in the Sūtra-samuccaya: “To contemplate the unconditioned and to be weary of conditioned wholesome [activities] is a deed of Māra.”

original: bodhimārga prajānāti pāramitāmārga ca na paryeṣata iti mārakarmeti /
analyzed: bodhi mārga prajānāti pāramitā mārga ca na paryeṣate iti māra karma iti
translated: “To know the path to enlightenment and not to seek the path of the perfections is a deed of Māra.”

original: yat punaḥ tatraivoktam dānacittābhiniveśād yāvat prajñācittābhiniveśāṃ mārakarmeti
analyzed: yat punar tatra eva uktam dāna citta abhiniveśāt yāvat prajñā citta abhiniveśām māra karma iti
translated: And again, it is said there: “To be attached to the thought of generosity up to being attached to the thought of wisdom is a deed of Māra.”

original: tatra na dānādināṃ sevāpratiṣedhaḥ kiṃ tvahaṃkāramamakāracittābhiniviṣṭasya grāhyagrāhakacittābhiniviṣṭasya
analyzed: tatra na dāna ādinām sevā pratiṣedhaḥ kim tu ahaṃkāra mamakāra citta abhiniviṣṭasya grāhya grāhaka citta abhiniviṣṭasya
translated: There, the practice of generosity and so on is not prohibited, but rather being attached to the thought of ‘I’ and ‘mine,’ being attached to the thought of grasped and grasper,

original: caupalambhikasya yo viparītābhiniveśo dānādau tasya pratiṣedhaḥ /
analyzed: ca aupalambhikasya yaḥ viparīta abhiniveśaḥ dāna ādau tasya pratiṣedhaḥ
translated: The denial of the one who perceives is the opposite attachment to giving, etc.

original: viparītābhiniveśasamuttthāpitā hi dānādayo 'pariśuddhā bhavantīti kṛtvā mārakarmetyuktam /
analyzed: viparīta abhiniveśa samuttthāpitāḥ hi dāna ādayaḥ pariśuddhāḥ bhavanti iti kṛtvā māra karma iti uktam
translated: For giving, etc. that are produced by opposite attachment become impure. Therefore, it is said to be the work of Mara.

original: anyathā dhyānam api na sevanīyaṃ syāt /
analyzed: anyathā dhyānam api na sevanīyam syāt
translated: Otherwise, even meditation would not be to be practiced.

original: tathā ca kathaṃ muktiḥ bhavet /🔽Bhk 🔽ata evaupalambhikasya sattvanānātvasaṃjñāyā yad dānādi tad apariśuddham iti pratipādanāya āryagaganagañje 'pi sattvanānātva viparītakarmasaṃjñino
analyzed: tathā ca katham muktiḥ bhavet  bhk  atas eva aupalambhikasya sattva nānātva saṃjñāyāḥ yat dāna ādi tat apariśuddham iti pratipādanāya ārya gaganagañje
translated: And how could there be liberation then?

analyzed: dāna ādi māra karma iti uktam
translated: For this very reason, in order to show that the giving, etc. of the one who perceives, who has the notion of the diversity of beings, is impure, it is said in the noble Gaganagañja Sūtra that giving, etc. of one who has the notion of the diversity of beings, which is produced by the opposite attachment, is the work of Mara.

original: yaccāpi triskandhapariṇāmanāyām uktam sarvam eva dānaśīlakṣāntivīryadhyānaprajñāsamatām ajānatopalambhayati /
analyzed: yat ca api tri skandha pariṇāmanāyām uktam sarvam eva dāna śīla kṣānti vīrya dhyāna prajñā samatām a jānatā upalambhayati
translated: And what is said in the Tripiṭaka's Transformation about all giving, morality, patience, vigor, meditation, and wisdom, not knowing their equality, one perceives.

analyzed: tena paryeṣṭita dānena parāmṛṣṭa śīlena śīlam rakṣitam
translated: By that sought-after giving, by that grasped morality, morality is guarded.

analyzed: ātma para saṃjñinā kṣāntiḥ bhāvitā ityādi tat pratideśayāmi iti
translated: By one who has the notion of self and others, patience is cultivated, and so on. I confess that.

original: tatrāpyaupalambhikasya nānatvasaṃjñino viparītābhiniveśasamutthāpitā dānādayo 'pi śuddhā bhavantīti etāvanmātraṃ pratipāditam /
analyzed: tatra api aupalambhikasya nānatva saṃjñinaḥ viparīta abhiniveśa samutthāpitāḥ dāna ādayaḥ śuddhāḥ bhavanti iti etāvat mātram pratipāditam
translated: Even there, it is taught that only the gifts, etc. of one who is attached to the idea of the reality of things and who has the notion of diversity, and which are produced by the erroneous attachment, are pure.

analyzed: na tu sarvathā dāna ādīnām sevana pratiṣedhaḥ
translated: But it is not at all a prohibition of the practice of giving, etc.

original: anyathā sarvasyaiva dānāderaviśeṣeṇa pratideśanā kṛtā syāt /
analyzed: anyathā sarvasya eva dāna ādeḥ aviśeṣeṇa pratideśanā kṛtā syāt
translated: Otherwise, it would have been a general confession of all giving, etc.

analyzed: na upalambha viparyāsa patitasya eva
translated: Not of one who has fallen into the error of the non-apprehension of things.

original: yaccāpi brahmaparipṛcchāyām uktam yāvatī caryā sarvā parikalpyā /
analyzed: yat ca api brahmaparipṛcchāyām uktam yāvatī caryā sarvā parikalpyā
translated: And what is said in the Brahmaparipṛcchā: “All practice is imagined,

analyzed: niṣparikalpyā ca bodhiḥ ityādi
translated: and enlightenment is non-imagined, etc.”

analyzed: tatra api utpāda ādi vikalpa caryāyāḥ prakṛta tvāt tasyāḥ parikalpa tvam uktam
translated: Even there, since the practice of the discrimination of origination, etc. is the subject, the imagined nature of that is stated.

original: animittavihāre cānabhisaṃskāravāhinaḥ sthitasya bodhisattvasya vyākaraṇaṃ bhavati /🔽nānyasyetyetāvanmātraṃ pratipāditam /
analyzed: animitta vihāre ca an abhisaṃskāra vāhinaḥ sthitasya bodhisattvasya vyākaraṇam bhavati  na anyasya iti etāvat mātram pratipāditam
translated: And the prediction of the bodhisattva who abides in the sphere of signlessness and is carried along without mental construction is stated.🔽It is taught that only that is so,

original: sarveṣāṃ ca dānādīnāṃ paramārthato 'nutpannatvaṃ ca paridīpitam /
analyzed: sarveṣām ca dāna ādīnām paramārthataḥ nutpanna tvam ca paridīpitam
translated: and it is also taught that all giving, etc. are ultimately unproduced.

analyzed: na tu caryā na kartavyā iti abhihitam
translated: But it is not said that practice should not be done.

original: anyathā hi dīpaṅkarāvadāne ye buddhā bhagavatā paryupāsitā yeṣāṃ tu kalpamapi bhagavatā🔽bhāṣamāṇena na śakyaṃ nāmaparikīrtnaṃ kathaṃ teṣāṃ bhagavatā bodhisattvāvasthāyāṃ
analyzed: anyathā hi dīpaṅkara avadāne ye buddhāḥ bhagavatā paryupāsitāḥ yeṣām tu kalpam api bhagavatā  bhāṣamāṇena na śakyam nāma parikīrtnam katham teṣām bhagavatā bodhisattva avasthāyām
translated: Otherwise, in the Avadana of Dipankara, the Buddhas whom the Blessed One served, whose names the Blessed One🔽could not recite even in a kalpa while speaking, how could the Blessed One, when he was a Bodhisattva,

analyzed: caryā pratiṣedhaḥ na kṛtaḥ
translated: have not prohibited the conduct of those [Buddhas]?

original: dīpaṅkareṇāpi tadānīṃ bhagavataścaryāpratiṣedho na kṛta eva /
analyzed: dīpaṅkareṇa api tadānīm bhagavataḥ caryā pratiṣedhaḥ na kṛtaḥ eva
translated: And Dipankara also at that time did not prohibit the Blessed One's conduct.

original: kiṃ tu yadā śāntānimittavihāre 'ṣṭamyāṃ bhūmau sthito 'sau dṛṣṭastadāsau vyākṛto bhagavatā /
analyzed: kim tu yadā śāntā nimitta vihāre ṣṭamyām bhūmau sthitaḥ sau dṛṣṭaḥ tadā asau vyākṛtaḥ bhagavatā
translated: But when he was seen to be abiding in the eighth stage of the peaceful signless abode, then he was prophesied by the Blessed One.

analyzed: tatra tasya caryā
translated: There his conduct

analyzed: a pratiṣiddhā
translated: was not prohibited.

original: sā cānimittavihāraparamatā bodhisattvānām aṣṭāmyāṃ bhūmau daśabhūmikairbuddhaiḥ pratiṣiddhā
analyzed: sā ca animitta vihāra parama tā bodhisattvānām aṣṭāmyām bhūmau daśa bhūmikaiḥ buddhaiḥ pratiṣiddhā
translated: And that supreme attainment of the signless abode of the Bodhisattvas in the eighth stage was prohibited by the Buddhas of the Dashabhumi [Sutra],

original: 'mā bhūd etad eva teṣāṃ parinirvāṇam' iti kṛtvā yadi tu sarvathā caryā na kartavyā
analyzed: mā bhūt etat eva teṣām parinirvāṇam iti kṛtvā yadi tu sarvathā caryā na kartavyā
translated: thinking, Let this not be their very nirvana. If, however, conduct were not to be done in any way,

analyzed: bhavet pūrva uktam sarva virudhyeta
translated: it would contradict everything previously stated.

original: yacca tatraiva brahmaparipṛcchāyām uktam dānaṃ ca dadāti taccāvipākābhikāṅkṣī /
analyzed: yat ca tatra eva brahmaparipṛcchāyām uktam dānam ca dadāti tat ca avipāka abhikāṅkṣī
translated: And what was said there in the Brahmaparipṛcchā: He gives gifts, but does not long for their ripening.

analyzed: śīlam ca rakṣati tat ca a samāropitaḥ ityādi
translated: And he guards morality, but without superimposition, and so on.

analyzed: caturbhiḥ brahma
translated: With four, he is endowed with the four Brahmā qualities.

original: dharmaiḥ samanvāgatā bodhisattvā avaivarttikā bhavanti buddhadharmeṣu /
analyzed: dharmaiḥ samanvāgatāḥ bodhisattvāḥ a vaivarttikāḥ bhavanti buddha dharmeṣu
translated: Bodhisattvas who are endowed with these four do not turn back from the Buddha-dharmas.

analyzed: katamaiḥ caturbhiḥ aparimita saṃsāra parigraheṇa aparimita buddha upasthāna pūjayā ityādi sarvam virudhyeta
translated: With which four? With the acceptance of immeasurable saṃsāra, with the worship and service of immeasurable Buddhas, and so on - all of this would be contradicted.

original: nāpi mṛdvindriyeṇaiva caryā kartavyā na tu tīkṣṇendriyeṇeti yuktaṃ vaktum /
analyzed: nā api mṛdu indriyeṇa eva caryā kartavyā na tu tīkṣṇa indriyeṇa iti yuktam vaktum
translated: And it is not appropriate to say that the practice should be done only by one with dull faculties, not by one with sharp faculties.

original: yataḥ prathamāṃ bhūmimupādāya yāvaddaśamībhūmipratiṣṭhitānāṃ bodhisattvānāṃ dānādicaryā utpadyate /
analyzed: yatas prathamām bhūmim upādāya yāvat daśamī bhūmi pratiṣṭhitānām bodhisattvānām dāna ādi caryā utpadyate
translated: Because it is said that the bodhisattvas who are established in the first stage up to the tenth stage give rise to the practice of generosity and so on,

original: na ca pariśiṣṭāsu na samudācaratīti vacanāt /
analyzed: na ca pariśiṣṭāsu na samudācarati iti vacanāt
translated: and that it does not operate in the remaining [stages].

analyzed: nahi bhūmi praviṣṭāḥ api mṛdu indriya ayuktāḥ
translated: For even those who have entered the stages are not suitable to have dull faculties.

original: āryopaliparipṛcchāyām anutpattikadharmakṣāntipratiṣṭhitenaiva tyāgamahātyāgātityāgāḥ kartavyāḥ iti varṇitam /
analyzed: ārya upali paripṛcchāyām anutpattikadharma kṣānti pratiṣṭhitena eva tyāga mahātyāga atityāgāḥ kartavyāḥ iti varṇitam
translated: In the noble Upāliparipṛcchā, it is described that only one who is established in the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas should practice giving, great giving, and ultimate giving.

original: sūtrasamuccaye ca ṣaṭpāramitādipratipattimān bodhisattvastathāgatarddhigatikaḥ iti varṇitam /
analyzed: sūtra samuccaye ca ṣaṣ pāramitā ādi pratipattimān bodhisattvaḥ tathāgata ṛddhi gatikaḥ iti varṇitam
translated: And in the Sūtrasamuccaya, it is described that the bodhisattva who possesses the practice of the six perfections and so on has the power and ability of the Tathāgata.

analyzed: na ca tathāgata ṛddhi gateḥ anyā śīghratarā gatiḥ asti
translated: And there is no speedier vehicle than the vehicle of the Tathāgata.

original: nāpi ṣaṭpāramitādaśabhūmivyatirekeṇānyo bodhisattvānāṃ mārgo 'sti yaḥ śīghrataravāhīsyāt /
analyzed: nā api ṣaṣ pāramitā daśa bhūmi vyatirekeṇa anyaḥ bodhisattvānām mārgaḥ sti yaḥ śīghratara vāhī syāt
translated: Nor is there any path for the bodhisattvas other than the six perfections and the ten stages that would be a faster carrier.

original: krameṇaiva ca cittasaṃtateḥ kanakaśuddhivat śuddhirbhavatīti sūtre varṇitam āryalaṅkāvatāradaśabhūmikādau coktaṃ tathatāyāṃ yadā sthito
analyzed: krameṇa eva ca citta saṃtateḥ kanaka śuddhi vat śuddhiḥ bhavati iti sūtre varṇitam ārya laṅkāvatāra daśa bhūmikā ādau ca uktam tathatāyām yadā
translated: And it is declared in the sūtras that the mind is purified by stages, like the purification of gold, and it is said in the noble Laṅkāvatāra, Daśabhūmika, etc., that when one abides in thusness,

analyzed: tadā prathamāyām bhūmau praviṣṭaḥ bhavati
translated: then one has entered the first stage.

original: tataḥ krameṇaiva pūrvabhūmīḥ pariśodhya tathāgatabhūmiṃ praviśatīti /
analyzed: tatas krameṇa eva pūrva bhūmīḥ pariśodhya tathāgata bhūmim praviśati iti
translated: Then by stages alone, having purified the previous stages, one enters the stage of the Tathāgata.

original: ato nāsti bhūmipāramitāvyatirekeṇa yugapat buddhatvapurapraveśe anyanmukhaṃ nāpi bhagavatā kvacit sūtrādau deśitam /🔽Bhk
analyzed: atas nā asti bhūmi pāramitā vyatirekeṇa yugapad buddhatva pura praveśe anyat mukham nā api bhagavatā kvacid sūtra ādau deśitam  bhk
translated: Therefore, apart from the stages and perfections, there is no other door for the simultaneous entry into the city of Buddhahood, nor has it been taught anywhere by the Blessed One in the sūtras, etc.

original: dhyāna eva ṣaṭpāramitāntargamāt tatsevanād eva sarvapāramitāḥ sevitā bhavantyato na dānādayaḥ anyapāramitāḥ pṛthak sevitavyā iti cet tad
analyzed: dhyāne eva ṣaṣ pāramitā antargamāt tad sevanāt eva sarva pāramitāḥ sevitāḥ bhavanti atas na dāna ādayaḥ anya pāramitāḥ pṛthak sevitavyāḥ iti ced tat
translated: If you think that since the six perfections are included in meditation alone, by practicing that alone all the perfections are practiced, so the perfections of generosity, etc. do not need to be practiced separately,🔽then that is not so.

original: evaṃ hi buddhe gomayamaṇḍale 'pi ṣaṭpāramitāntargamān maṇḍalakam eva kartavyaṃ syānna dhyānādyāḥ /
analyzed: evam hi buddhe gomaya maṇḍale pi ṣaṣ pāramitā antargamāt maṇḍalakam eva kartavyam syāt na dhyāna ādyāḥ
translated: For in this way, even in the cow-dung mandala, the mandala alone would have to be performed, with the six perfections included in it, and not the meditations and so on.

original: śrāvakasyāpi nirodhasamādhisamāpannasya nimittād eva asamudācārāt tadā ṣaṭpāramitāparipūriprasaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: śrāvakasya api nirodha samādhi samāpannasya nimittāt eva a samudācārāt tadā ṣaṣ pāramitā paripūri prasaṅgaḥ
translated: And for a śrāvaka who has entered the concentration of cessation, there would be the consequence of the fulfillment of the six perfections at that time, because of the non-occurrence of signs.

original: tataśca na śrāvakebhyo bodhisattvānāṃ bhedaḥ pratipādito bhavet /
analyzed: tatas ca na śrāvakebhyaḥ bodhisattvānām bhedaḥ pratipāditaḥ bhavet
translated: And from that, it would not be taught that there is a distinction between bodhisattvas and śrāvakas.

original: sarvāvasthāyām eva tu bodhisattvena ṣaṭpāramitāḥ paripūrayitavyā iti saṃdarśanārthe ekaikapāramitāntarbhāvaḥ sarvapāramitānāṃ bhagavatā sandarśitaḥ
analyzed: sarva avasthāyām eva tu bodhisattvena ṣaṣ pāramitāḥ paripūrayitavyāḥ iti saṃdarśana arthe ekaika pāramitā antarbhāvaḥ sarva pāramitānām bhagavatā sandarśitaḥ
translated: But in order to show that the bodhisattva must fulfill the six perfections in all states, the Blessed One showed that each perfection includes all the perfections.

original: na punarekaiva pāramitā sevanīyeti /🔽tathā coktaṃ sarvadharmavaipulye yo 'pyayaṃ maitreya/
analyzed: na punar ekā eva pāramitā sevanīyā iti  tathā ca uktam sarva dharma vaipulye yaḥ pi ayam maitreya
translated: It is not that only one perfection should be practiced.

original: ṣaṭpāramitāsamudāgamo bodhisattvānāṃ saṃbodhāya taṃ te mohapuruṣā evaṃ vakṣyanti /
analyzed: ṣaṣ pāramitā samudāgamaḥ bodhisattvānām saṃbodhāya tam te moha puruṣāḥ evam vakṣyanti
translated: And it is said in the Vaipulya of all dharmas: Maitreya, this attainment of the six perfections by the bodhisattvas for the sake of complete enlightenment, those deluded people will say thus:

analyzed: prajñāpāramitāyām evam bodhisattvena śikṣitavyam
translated: The bodhisattva should train in the perfection of wisdom in this way.

analyzed: kim śeṣābhiḥ pāramitābhiḥ iti
translated: What is the use of the remaining perfections?

analyzed: te nyāḥ pāramitāḥ dūṣayitavyāḥ maṃsyante
translated: They will think that the other perfections should be criticized.

original: tat kiṃ manyase / ajita/🔽duṣprajñaḥ sa kāśirājo 'bhūt /
analyzed: tat kim manyase ajita  duṣprajñaḥ sa kāśirājaḥ bhūt
translated: What do you think, Ajita?

analyzed: yena kapota arthena śyenāya sva māṃsāni dattāni
translated: Was that king of Kāśi, by whom his own flesh was given to the hawk for the sake of the dove, unwise?

analyzed: maitreyaḥ āha no hi idam bhagavan
translated: Maitreya said: No indeed, Blessed One.

analyzed: bhagavān āha yāni mayā maitreya
translated: The Blessed One said: Maitreya,

analyzed: bodhisattva caryām caratā ṣaṣ pāramitā pratisaṃyuktāni kuśala mūlāni upacitāni
translated: while I was practicing the conduct of a bodhisattva, I accumulated roots of virtue connected with the six perfections.

analyzed: apakṛtam nu taiḥ kuśala mūlaiḥ
translated: Have those roots of virtue been harmful?

analyzed: maitreyaḥ āha
translated: Maitreya said:

analyzed: no hi idam bhagavan
translated: No indeed, Blessed One.

analyzed: bhagavān āha tvam tāvat ajita
translated: The Blessed One said: You, Ajita,

analyzed: ṣaṣṭi kalpān dānāpāramitāyām samudāgataḥ
translated: have been perfecting the perfection of generosity for sixty eons.

analyzed: evam yāvat ṣaṣṭi kalpān prajñāpāramitāyām samudāgataḥ
translated: Likewise, you have been perfecting the perfection of wisdom for sixty eons.

analyzed: tat te moha puruṣāḥ evam vakṣyanti
translated: Those deluded people will say:

original: ekanayenaiva bodhiryaduta śūnyatānayeneti te caryāpariśuddhā bhavanti ityādi /
analyzed: eka nayena eva bodhiḥ yat uta śūnyatā nayena iti te caryā pariśuddhāḥ bhavanti ityādi
translated: Enlightenment is by a single method, namely the method of emptiness. They will be impure in conduct, and so on.

original: kevalaṃ śūnyātām eva sevamānāḥ śrāvakavannirvāṇe patanti /
analyzed: kevalam śūnyātām eva sevamānāḥ śrāvaka vat nirvāṇe patanti
translated: Practicing only emptiness, they will fall into nirvāṇa like the śrāvakas.

analyzed: atas upāya sahitā prajñā sevanīyā
translated: Therefore, wisdom accompanied by skillful means should be practiced.

original: ata evācāryanāgārjunapādaiḥ sūtrasamuccaye 'bhihitam na copāyakauśalarahitena bodhisattvena gambhīradharmatāyāmabhiyoktavyam iti /
analyzed: atas eva ācārya nāgārjuna pādaiḥ sūtrasamuccaye bhihitam na ca upāya kauśala rahitena bodhisattvena gambhīra dharmatāyām abhiyoktavyam iti
translated: For this very reason, it is said by the teacher Nāgārjuna in the Sūtra-samuccaya: “And a bodhisattva who is devoid of skillful means should not be intent on the profound nature of things.”

analyzed: atra bhk ārya vimalakīrti nirdeśa ādi jñāpakaḥ taiḥ upanyastaḥ
translated: Here, the noble Vimalakīrti-nirdeśa and others are cited as proof by them.

analyzed: na ca ācārya nāgārjunapādīyam vacanam
translated: And this is not the statement of the teacher Nāgārjuna.

original: yuktayāgamopetaṃ tyaktvā bhagavadvacanaṃ ca parityajya anyasya mūrkhajanasya vacanaṃ prekṣāvatā grahītum ayuktam /
analyzed: yuktayā āgama upetam tyaktvā bhagavat vacanam ca parityajya anyasya mūrkha janasya vacanam prekṣāvatā grahītum ayuktam
